0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Cystinuria: initial, 800 mg/day ORALLY in 3 divided doses; adjust to maintain urinary cystine concentration below its solubility limit (generally less than 250 mg/L)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy have not been established in children less than 9 y
  • Cystinuria: (9 y and older) 15 mg/kg/day in 3 divided doses, followed by adjustment to maintain urinary cystine below its solubility limit (generally less than 250 mg/L)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• history of myelosuppression while on tiopronin
  • pregnancy and lactation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono: adverse reactions more likely among patients who have shown toxicity to d-penicillamine

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Disorder of skin, Including pharyngitis, oral ulcers (17%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal symptom (17%), Taste sense altered (4%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (4%)
  • Other:Sense of smell altered (4%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Aplastic anemia, Leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Drug-induced lupus erythematosus, Fever, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy
  • Renal:Kidney disease (5%)
  • Other:Drug fever

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Tiopronin is an active reducing agent that undergoes thiol-disulfide exchange with cystine (cysteine-cysteine disulfide) to form tiopronin-cystine disulfide, which is more water-soluble than cystine and is readily excreted. As a result, urinary cystine calculi are prevented.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • administer 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals
  • administer at least 3 L of fluids per day including 2 glasses with each meal and at bedtime

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement, reduction in stone formation
  • urinary cystine levels; at 1 mo, then every 3 mo
  • 24-h urinary protein, urinalysis, CBC, serum electrolytes, hepatic function; 3-6 mo intervals
  • abdominal ultrasound of kidney, ureters, and bladder; yearly

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause oral ulcers or gastrointestinal symptoms including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, or abdominal pain.
  • Fever is more likely to develop during the first month of therapy. Tell patient to report fever.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of kidney disease.
  • Patient should drink at least 3 L of liquids per day including 2 glasses with each meal and at bedtime, unless otherwise specified by healthcare professional.
  • Tell patient to take drug 1 h before or 2 h after meals.
